awd_titl_txt: Expanding Educational Opportunities for Nondestructive Testing Technicians
awd_abstract_narration:
The demand among companies in the United States for skilled technicians in nondestructive testing (NDT) is growing at a steady rate. These technicians ensure the quality and safety of manufactured products in industries such as aerospace, construction, manufacturing, and transportation. Companies typically create their own internal training programs. The technician employees earn certifications that may only be recognized at a specific company or include only a few types of testing methods. A limited number of educational institutions offer courses or programs in NDT technology. To keep up with the increasing workforce demand for NDT technicians, the nation needs more educational programs that provide complete professional preparation. To meet this need, Lorain County Community College will collaborate with two national industry associations and leading employers of technicians to identify the required skills, student learning outcomes, and best practices for NDT programs. The project has the potential to enhance the preparation of future NDT technicians to meet the need in the nation's workforce. 

This project main goal is to develop the capacity of community colleges to educate students for jobs in the NDT technician workforce. The project will involve collaboration between Lorain County Community College, the American Society for Nondestructive Testing, the American Welding Society Foundation, and industry partners. It will build upon results from two prior NSF-funded projects at Chattanooga State Community College and Iowa State University that focused in this technology area. Both institutions will also collaborate to accomplish project activities. The collaborators will perform a job task analysis for one technician job level. The results will then be combined with existing job task analyses for the other job levels.  This synthesis aims to create comprehensive competency models for NDT technicians. These competency models will be used to define the desirable student learning outcomes for an associate degree that includes stackable credentials. Educators, along with subject matter experts in industry, will review and validate these learning outcomes. A framework for implementing NDT courses and programs will be developed, documented, and disseminated. The existing professional development program, Weld-Ed Module 7, for high school, community college, and university faculty will also be refined and tested at Lorain County Community College. Approaches to promote awareness of NDT technology and career pathways will be developed and implemented. These strategies will emphasize the inclusion of underrepresented groups and veterans to enhance the diversity of the workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Back in the summer of 2015, the Director of Weld-Ed Duncan Estep drove 120 miles south on Interstate 71 from Weld-Ed headquarters at Lorain County Community College (LCCC) in Elyria to Columbus Ohio for a meeting with American Association of Nondestructive Testing (ASNT) management at their home base including Technical Officer James Bennett and Director Heather Cowles. Weld-Ed The National Center for Welding Education and Training was at the end of its second round of funding as a National Center of Excellence and the leadership team was looking for ways to expand on its core competencies of instructor professional development, curriculum development, student outreach, and industry demand research. Traditionally, nondestructive testing was, and still is, a skill passed down through apprenticeship and hands-on experience in the field.  Duncan knew the interconnected relationship between welding and nondestructive testing and thought Weld-Ed could help to standardize NDT education.

After roughly a year and a half of discussion, the following goals were solidified and included in the grant entitled “Expanding Educational Opportunities for Nondestructive Testing Technicians”: 1 Codify the skills required for Levels 1 NDT technicians; 2 Identify student learning outcomes for an NDT associate degree with stackable certificates; 3 Assemble best practices to assist community colleges in adapting and adopting NDT courses and programs; and 4 Develop an NDT awareness program for students.

After getting partner subawards in place and establishing regular telephone meetings with the project leadership team, the next order of business was to conduct nondestructive testing curriculum research using the DACUM method. The resulting DACUM chart, consisting of sixty task statements, fifteen skill sets, and around 125 listed tools, equipment, and supplies required for everything that needs to be accomplished in the field for an NDT Level 1 technician, set the stage for the development of Level 1 and 2 Student Learning Outcomes, which is the foundation for curriculum-based education.  The project leveraged an earlier task analysis conducted by ANDE for Level 2 NDT technicians. The next step was to turn these task statements into Student Learning Outcomes. Dr. Polanin, professor from Illinois Central College leveraged the Weld-Ed partner by surveying Weld-Ed partners and affiliates to determine the most critical tasks. The resulting curriculum guide is a free resource for anyone interested in building the educational component of a two-year NDT program.

To achieve Goal 3, Weld-Ed co-PI Tracie Clifford developed a “white paper” entitled “Implementing a Successful NDT Educational Program: Planning, Design, Resources, Curriculum, and Evaluation”. The paper was published in Materials Evaluation Magazine in September 2021. The seven-page article outlines much of the major focus areas and recommendations that a program would need to launch a two-year NDT program.

Another resource widely used by a community of educators is the site NDE-ED.org. The site has a vast database of every main nondestructive test, explains the science and math reasoning for each test, lesson plans, case studies, and real-world applications for each. Partner ASNT contracted the team at Iowa State University. The newly renovated site went live in March, 2021 and gets over 150,000 hits per day on average. Site architecture should last ten to twenty years before another major renovation is required, according to the design team.

To address goal 4: develop and NDT awareness program for students, Weld-Ed PI and American Welding Society Foundation Executive Director, Monica Pfarr had the idea to leverage an existing recruitment resource, The Careers-In-Welding Mobile Exhibit. Monica’s idea was to install a “Discover NDT” interactive display within the trailer. The display gives visitors the chance to see NDT in action on the monitor, get their hands on NDT equipment, and learn about what it takes to become an NDT technician. The Careers-In-Welding trailer travels to around a dozen of the biggest agricultural and manufacturing trade shows and family friendly events in the country. Since the display was installed, the trailer attended 28 events, saw 88 event days, and hosted over 53,000 visitors.

Intellectual Merit

The project team was able to leverage their experience with curriculum development, program development, and outreach to create and/or update resources to give interested communities everything they need to begin and maintain an NDT two-year associate degree level program. Weld-Ed also has an instructor professional development workshop “Module 7: Nondestructive Testing”. This forty-hour in-person summer training covers methodology to detect common metal defects and failure mechanisms, such as cracking and corrosion by utilizing different detection methods such as radiographic inspection, ultrasonic inspection, and magnetic particle inspection.

Broader Impacts

The numerous resources created and updated through this project including The NDT Technician Core Curriculum Guide, the “White Paper” the website and the interactive display can be utilized as examples and in some cases adapted to fit the needs of any technological/advanced manufacturing program.  The resources are freely available at the following websites: Weld-Ed.org, NDE-ED.org, or Careers-In-Welding.com.
